text: FADE IN on a gray, drizzly morning. We are gliding behind YOUNG WOMAN as she jogs down a leaf-strewn path. She has lean, athletic body. We follow her for a good while.
It starts with me running. My usual route. It’s early, so the park is completely empty. Presently, the woman slows to a stop, her shoulders rhythmically rising and falling as she breathes.
Attractive, intense, with soulful brown eyes. This is CAS BELL (19). Casey stares at an object on the ground -- a R KNIT GLOVE. She picks it up. As she rises, she tenses --
Then I get the feeling that someone is watching me. She slowly turns around --

Stands in the path. He is pale, with haunted eyes, dresse in clothes a half-century out of date. On his left hand i the matching glove. We will come to know this boy as BART Casey stares at the boy, gripped by rising apprehension - only now a DOG sits in the boy’s place, resting on its haunches. A bull terrier. A papier-maché mask of the boy’ face is strapped to the dog’s head with red ribbon.
The dog trots off into the nearby trees. Casey follows.

Casey pushes her way through branches and brambles, comin upon the discarded mask. The dog is nowhere to be found. Casey reaches for the mask, but realizes that the end of ribbon is buried in the soil. She digs with her fingers, unearthing a MASON JAR. Casey brushes dirt from it.
A HUMAN EMBRYO rests within formaldehyde. About nine week into development. Suddenly, the embryo OPENS ITS EYES.
ROMY’S VOICE That’s disgusting.
The lights are off and Casey is nestled on a couch, a cellphone in one hand, a fashion magazine open on her lap TV is on, the sound muted.
I know. So what does the dream mean? INT. MARSHALL HOUSE - ROMY’S BEDROOM - NIGHT (INTERCUT) ROMY MARSHALL (19), Casey’s slightly neurotic best friend leafs through a book on dream symbols.
That your vagina is completely disease-infested.
Shut up. For real. Romy sighs, reads from the page in question.

“Babies are symbolic of change and renewal. If the baby is a stranger to you, it may represent something developing within yourself that is not yet ready to be born.” (beat, deadpan) It doesn’t say anything about babies in formaldehyde.
Casey stretches out, slinking further down into the couch
What about dogs?  ROMY’S VOICE It doesn’t say anything about dogs in formaldehyde either.

Fuck you, Romy. ROMY’S VOICE Okay, okay -- (sighing, flipping pages) “Depending on its actions, a dog May represent the dreamer’s natural drives and instincts, whether they be restrained or unleashed. In mythology the dog was often seen as the guardian of the afterlife, or a messenger between the visible and the hidden --" Then it just goes on with more psycho-babble. (beat) Forget about it. So how were the kids? Did you have to change diapers and shit like that?
(laughing) No. The baby was down when I got here. And the four year-old conked out as soon as I read to him. ROMY’S VOICE Do you think they have a nanny-cam?
Come on. ROMY’S VOICE I would if I had kids. There’s no way I'd trust them with some random teenager. (conspiratorially) Do you think they have any porn in their DVD collection?
Like I really want to know what Mr. Neilson beats off to. ROMY’S VOICE Well it’s not Mrs. Neilson, that’s for sure. (MORE )

ROMY’S VOICE (CONT'D) You know, Lisa was sitting for the Stapletons and she found, like full- on gay porn in their media closet. Just then, a THUMP sounds from overhead. Casey looks towa the ceiling, suddenly alert.

Hold on. ANOTHER THUMP. Definitely coming from upstairs. Casey lea over the coffee table, reaching for a baby monitor. She turns up the volume, listening. We slowly PUSH IN on the monitor. Through the HISSING STA a barely discernible WHISPER. Unintelligible, and then:
Some people are doorways.
Casey turns on a light, peering up the carpeted stairs to landing above. She calls out.
Matty? You up? No answer. Casey starts up the stairs.
(into phone) Romy, hang on. I think one of the kids is awake.
At the end of the hall, light shines out from the open nursery door. Casey approaches with mild trepidation.
Matty?

As she rounds the corner MATTY NEILSON (5) becomes framed the doorway, clad in superhero pajamas. A chair has been pulled beside the crib. Matty stands on it, leaning over crib rail, holding a small mirror. He pivots the mirror b and forth, reflecting light into the baby’s face.

What are you doing, Matty? Matty doesn’t respond. He is intent upon his task. CASEY (CONT’D) Matty. Again, no response. Casey steps forward, gently tugging a the boy’s arm. He resists her. Then the baby begins to CR and Casey renews her efforts.

Matty, stop that. Suddenly, Matty twists around and SMASHES the mirror into Casey's face. The mirror SHATTERS and Casey staggers back dropping her cell phone. She stares at Matty, stunned. CASEY (CONT’D)
Matty glares back, emotionless, hands immobile at his sid

Jumby wants to be born now. And just like that, whatever spell has taken hold of Matt seems to lift. He seems disoriented. Then he begins to WA On the floor, Romy’S VOICE is heard from the fallen phone ROMY’S VOICE Casey? What’s going on there?

Some time later, Casey stands opposite ROGER and GAIL NEI (30s), who have returned from their night on the town. Bo are apologetic, agitated. Gail holds the baby in her arms Casey dabs at her left cheek with a Kleenex, having recei what amounts to little more than a scratch.
Are you sure you’re alright?
It’s fine, it’s nothing.
I can’t even imagine what got into him. He’s never done anything like that before.
I probably just startled him. Honestly, he was more upset than I was afterwards.
All the same, I'd feel better if you had your eye checked out. Embarrassed and anxious to put the whole thing past her, Casey edges towards the front door.
I will. I promise.

It’s quiet. Just the sound of WIND CHIMES coming from a neighbor's porch. Casey exits, the Neilsons trailing her Halfway down their driveway, she pauses and waves, then s in a catty-corner direction across the street towards --

An upper middle-class Colonial Revival with an S-class bl Mercedes parked in front. As Casey approaches her house, she pauses. On the ground a_RED KNIT GLOVE. Casey freezes, eyes wide. She fearfully looks behind her -- but no one is there. Casey looks back to the glove. She shakes her head, dismissing it as nothing. But as she continues onward, sh gives the glove a wide berth.
Casey enters, shedding her coat at the door, trying to sh the feeling of unease. We FOLLOW HER into the livingroom.
Hey, Dad. Allison. GORDON BELL (40s), is cuddling on the couch with his girlfriend, ALLISON THAYER (30s). They’re watching a movi
How was sitting, Casey?
(not wanting to engage) Fine. Though they’re cordial enough, we sense that Casey and Allison aren't particularly friendly.
There’s cheesecake from Ricardo’s, if you want it.
Thanks, but I think I’m just going to crash. Night, you guys. Casey continues on her way.

Casey, now wearing a T-shirt and panties, stands at the s She opens the medicine cabinet, takes out her birth contr pills, pops one from a blister pack and downs it. As she closes the medicine cabinet, she inspects the scra on her cheek in the mirror. It’s minor. She turns off the bathroom light, exits. A few steps into her darkened bedroom, she pauses. There’ TAPPING behind her, like someone rapping on a window pane Casey turns. It’s coming from behind the cabinet mirror.
Casey opens the medicine cabinet. There’s nothing inside toiletries. She shuts it again, dismissing it as nothing.
Casey climbs in bed. She stares at the ceiling, then look to a framed photo -- CASEY as a GIRL, laughing in the arm a WOMAN (30s). Casey studies the photo, shuts her eyes.
Slowly PUSH IN. The TAPPING is heard again, but slightly lower in volume now. FADE TO BLACK.

FADE IN as Casey hurriedly fixes breakfast. The TV is on, some inane morning show. Casey has a pan on the stove, so eggs ready nearby. She pours herself a glass of juice, ch it down. Then she cracks one of the eggs open into the pa As it SIZZLES, she reaches for a second egg, cracks it to

Something squirms amidst the yolk. A creepy-crawly POTATO BUG, over an inch long. It’s on its back, legs writhing. Casey gags, dumping the pan’s contents into a wastebasket Thoroughly grossed out, she looks through the window abov the sink -- at the Neilsons’ house across the street.

And that was all the kid said? EXT. GARRISON COMMUNITY COLLEGE —- COMMONS - DAY Casey sits at a table with her boyfriend, MARK HARDIGAN, has his arm draped around her. He’s tall, good-looking, thoughtful. The perfect boyfriend. Across from them are Romy and LISA SHEPHERD, another student. It’s lunchtime.
Yeah. “Jumby wants to be born now.” And then he hit me.
That’s creepy.
The kid’s four. He probably didn’t even know what he was doing.
It’s bad luck, you know.
Breaking the mirror?
Well, that. But what he was doing with it, too. Newborns aren’t supposed to see their own reflections until they’re at least a year old. It means they’1l die soon.
According to who?
It’s just one of those superstitions.
You're completely fucked in the head.
(defensive) It’s not like I believe it. It’s just one of those things.
Where do you get all this useless information? It’s amazing.

I read, okay? You should try it some time. They string all these words together on a page and they spell out a message. It’s awesome. Mark rolls his eyes, making a “retardo” face. Lisa, meanwhile, has lost interest in the conversation and is checking her text messages.
Hey, you guys want to go to St. Andrews on Saturday night? Brandon’s brother is DJing.
I'd be up for that. Mark nods as well, but he’s got his eye on Casey, who loo preoccupied. She catches him watching her, smiles at him. Just then, the SCHOOL BELL RINGS.

Casey sits near the back, a few rows away from Mark. She’ got a notebook open and is doing her best to pay attentio MR. SHIELDS (30s), cute and energetic by professor standa paces before the chalkboard at the head of the class. He’ already written the day’s subject on the board: “THE GREAT IMPONDERABLES”.  10. Now he’s finishing a question beneath that. “WHAT HAPPENED BEFORE TIME BEGAN?”

As far as we know, the universe is roughly fifteen billion years old. So if the universe had a beginning, what happened before the beginning? Shields scans the faces of his students. They’re stumped. Casey blinks, distracted. She rubs her left eye (the one Matty had hit) as if she had something in it.

Okay. Fair enough. People have been wracking their brains over that one for thousands of years. Einstein would tell us that there was no before, since time itself didn’t exist yet. Casey continues to feel discomfort. She’s got an itch, so she scratches behind her ear, brushing her hair away.
Her vision WARPS, the words on the blackboard blurring.

So here’s another question -- how big is the universe? Mr. Shields turns to the board, writing a second question “HOW BIG IS THE UNIVERSE?” Casey shuts her eyes, massaging her temples. She opens th again. From her perspective, the new question now reads: “JUMBY WANTS TO BE BORN NOW.” Casey looks at her notes, SEES that she’s written the sam statement repeatedly, covering virtually the entire page.
Does the universe go on forever? And if it doesn’t go on forever, then what’s beyond the edge? A STUDENT raises his hand and Shields nods to him.  11.
Nothing?

Maybe yes, maybe no. Here’s the catch. Since our universe was created, the light from the Big Bang has been steadily travelling outward. Now by definition, nothing’s faster than light -- so we'd never be able to catch up to that boundary. Be even if we did, you could never go beyond it, because space itself bends. You'd wind up back where you started. It'd be like walking into a mirror. Casey looks back to the board once more, SEES that the question has reverted to its original state. She feels another itch, brushes her hair away again. But when she brings her hand back in front of her face she SEES --
Crawling across her hand, like the one in the egg yolk!
Casey SCREAMS, flinging the bug onto the floor. She STOMP on it repeatedly. The others look at her, concerned.
Is everything alright, Casey? INT. COMMUNITY COLLEGE - WOMEN’S GYM - DAY Casey is in the showers with a few OTHER GIRLS, clutching herself beneath the warm spray, tuning out the CHATTER.
Casey stands at a sink, brushing out her hair. Romy is th too, wrapped in a towel, applying makeup.

-- so then he texted me the day after we went out. “I miss you”. But when I texted him back, he never replied. And that was like two days ago. What do you think’s up with that? Should I call him?  12.
He’s probably seeing someone else too.
So why bother saying he misses me, then?
He probably texted both of you. He was seeing who would answer first. It was a booty text.
Case -- Casey looks up, registering concern on Romy’s face.
There’s something wrong with your eye.
What are you talking about?
Go look. Romy nods to the mirror. Casey looks. CLOSE ON CASEY’S LEFT EYE The eye Matty struck. A_good portion of her brown iris ha turned BRIGHT BLUE. Casey blinks and we --
THE SAME EYE, the pupil constricting as light shines over

It’s called heterochromia, meaning one iris is a different color than the other. Usually, it’s congenital. REVEAL Casey in an examination chair, her hands rigidly clasping the armrests. Mark sits beside her, while DR. CALDWELL (50s) inspects her eye with an ophthalmoscope.  13. DR. CALDWELL (CONT’D) Normally, it’s the entire iris. Sectoral or partial discolorations like this are much more uncommon.
Is it dangerous?

Not in of itself. Sometimes it occurs after blunt trauma. Blood might pool in the anterior chamber and you'll get iron deposits. On very rare occasions it might be indicative of a melanomatous tumor. In order to rule that out I’1l need to take a few digital pictures. Caldwell sets down the scope and reaches for another devi DR. CALDWELL (CONT’D) This is a retinal camera. We put a little topical gel on your cornea and the imagining head rests directly on top of that. It feels a bit strange, but it’s perfectly safe. I’11 put some anaesthetic eye-drops in first.

Okay. Caldwell applies the eye-drops, then reaches to a tray wh a Q-tip rests in a dish of gel. Casey grasps Mark’s hand. Caldwell spreads apart the lids her left eye with his thumb and forefinger. With the othe hand, he gently applies the gel to the surface of her cor

Now you'll feel some mild pressure. Try not to blink, alright? Caldwell picks up the handheld camera and positions the imaging head directly onto her eye. Mark winces, focusing instead on a nearby LCD monitor where a real-time view of anterior segment of Casey’s eye can be seen. DR. CALDWELL (CONT’D) Okay. We’re done.  14. Caldwell removes the camera and Casey blinks reflexively. Caldwell swivels his chair over to the LCD screen and use mouse to click through the captured images.
See anything?

(shaking his head) Not really. No evidence of any hemorrhaging or lesions. (turning back) I admit I’m stumped. I’d like to run a blood panel, just to be safe. I’m also going to recommend an MRI of the surrounding orbital cavity. INT. MARK’S CAR - DAY Mark drives while Casey lounges in the passenger seat, he head propped against the window. She’s watching the passi landscape, wearing a pair of those dark, disposable sunglasses that are given to eye patients post-examinatio

Her vision is blurry, with halation obscuring any bright highlights. Up ahead, a MAN is walking a bull terrier alo the road. As we pass by, the dog looks up at the car -- i wearing the papier-maché mask from Casey’s dream. Casey does a double-take. She removes her sunglasses, sta rubbing her eyes.
Jesus. Mark glances over at her, concerned.
Does it hurt?
No. The light’s just a little bright because of the eye-drops. Casey forces a smile and reaches for Mark's hand.
Thanks for driving me.  15.
No problem.
You want to stay over for a while? My Dad won’t be back from his deposition until tomorrow morning.
So does that mean you’re feeling frisky?
(shrugging) Maybe.

Awesome, cause those glasses are definitely giving me a boner. Casey rolls her eyes, puts the dorky glasses back on. INT. BELL HOME - CASEY’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Casey and Mark are just finishing having sex. Mark rolls off, winded. Casey rests her head on his chest. They stay that way for a while, lost in their own private thoughts.
It really screws with your head.
What?
The whole idea that the universe doesn’t have an end.
That's what you were thinking about just now? Mark props himself up on an elbow.

When I was a kid, there was this picture book on myths that I used to check out from the library. And there was this one entry about how the American Indians believed that the whole world rested on the back of a giant turtle. (MORE )
And I guess someone asked this Indian chief, “well what’s underneath the turtle?” And the chief shot back that it was turtles all the way down. Casey smiles at this.

And that’s what the picture showed - - the world on this huge turtle, then another turtle beneath that one, and so on. All these turtles dwindling away into the distance. Mark pauses, finding himself oddly haunted by the memory.

And for some reason, that picture always upset me. I couldn’t wrap my head around there being these turtles going on forever. I’d try to imagine what it would feel like if you fell off and were falling past them. Knowing that you’d never land. That you’d just keep falling forever.
I still get that way when I think about dying.
You don’t think there’s an afterlife? After a long beat, Casey answers:
No.
Why? Casey turns around now, searching Mark’s eyes with her ow
Because I don’t feel her anywhere. Mark looks to the nearby photo of Casey and her Mom, then pulls her closer, as much for his own comfort as hers.  Mark nods. 17.
I remember the last time I saw her. We went to the hospital. She was just sitting there in her room, staring into the corner. It was like she was already gone.
Did she say anything to you?
Yeah. She said she’d found out who her mother was.
What do you mean?
Well, she was adopted. And she never knew who her birth mother was. So I guess she found out or something.
So who was it?

She never said. The next day she was dead. (beat) They say it takes a really long time when you hang yourself, that sometimes people have second thoughts, but then they can’t do anything about it. (shaking her head) I used to hate her for leaving us. What can he possibly say? Then he notices the time on the bedside table clock -- 11:11.
Hey, four sticks.
Hmmm?
(re: clock) 11:11. Close your eyes and make a wish. Casey shuts her eyes, thinks. The clock changes to 11:12.

Okay, good. You got that one. Casey opens her eyes and smiles. Then she sits up, gives Mark a kiss, reaches for a robe at the foot of the bed. INT. The patch of discoloration in the afflicted iris is growi Disturbed, Casey flips off the light and exits -- -- but only gets a few steps before she stops. She hears that TAPPING again, coming from within the medicine cabin Casey opens the cabinet. As before, nothing is amiss. Jus a bunch of toiletries inside. Casey removes a couple of t larger items, checking behind them, but there’s hardly ro to conceal anything hidden. Feeling foolish, Casey returns the items and shuts the cabinet. But even as she steps away, the TAPPING resumes. Casey stares at the cabinet. It’s not her imagination. Th sound is definitely coming from behind the mirror. Summon her strength, Casey flings open the cabinet --

Mark is there in an instant, having pulled on his boxers.
What, what --?! Casey points to the partially closed medicine cabinet --
Inside -- inside it!!! Mark cautiously swings the cabinet open -- but the boy is gone. Mark steps aside, offering Casey a clear view.  19.
I don’t see anything. Was it a spider or something? Casey stands, drawing closer. Everything in the cabinet i as it was before. Her brow furrows.
Mark, now fully dressed, is at the front door. Casey, sti in her robe, is seeing him out.
You sure you’re okay? Because I can stay.
It’s fine, honestly. I just need some sleep.

Okay. But if you get freaked out, you call me, alright? Any time. Casey nods. They kiss and Mark exits. After Casey shuts t front door, she leans against it, collecting herself. It’s the baby. She wasn’t breathing. Just then, a CORONER INVESTIGATOR and a FORENSIC ASSISTAN exit the house, maneuvering a wheeled gurney onto the walkway. A TINY FIGURE covered by a sheet has been belted a backboard. Gail Neilson rushes alongside it, sobbing.

shaken. Then she catches sight of Matty in the Neilson’s upstairs window. He makes eye-contact with Casey. As if t two of them shared some hidden knowledge. Casey edges awa

As you can see, there’s no evidence of a tumor or any other kind of pathology. So we can rule out retinoblastoma. (beat) But there was one oddity -- 21. the results it. Dr. Caldwell reaches for a clipboard with various test results. He studies them a beat, then looks up at Casey. DR. CALDWELL (CONT’D) Are you a twin by any chance, Ms. Bell?
No. I’m an only child.
Hmmm. Are you familiar with the term genetic mosaicism?
Uh, no.

It’s a medical condition in which an individual has two or more genetically-distinct cell populations. For instance, a person might have more than one blood type, which happens to be the case with you. You're predominantly type-A, but then you’ve got a little B as well.
How is that possible?  22.

Well, occasionally, when you’re dealing with twins, the placentas can become fused and a certain amount of blood will be exchanged back and forth. If you did have a twin, I suppose the emerging pigmentation in your affected iris could be a result of that foreign genetic strand. (beat) I don’t think it’s anything you need to worry about. But you may want to see a genetic counselor, just to be on the safe side.

INT. LAW FIRM —- CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY Gordon is in the midst of a heated deposition for a divor case. Sitting with him are the WIFE, her HUSBAND, his ATTORNEY, and a COURT REPORTER. The wife is upset, while husband projects an air of hostile detachment.
Now Ms. Beckett, as difficult as this may be, I need you to recount for us how you came upon your husband and the woman in question.

I was on his computer, looking for a recipe online -- and I happened to check the history menu on the web navigator. There was a page for this bed and breakfast -- Someone KNOCKS. Gordon looks up, SEES his SECRETARY in th doorway. He shakes his head, trying to will her to leave.

Sir, I’m sorry -- (approaching, sotto) Your daughter’s here. She’s quite upset. INT. LAW FIRM —- GORDON’S OFFICE - DAY Gordon enters his well-appointed office, SEES Casey stand by the window, defensively hugging her arms.  23.
I got my test results back. Gordon stops short, concerned.
It’s okay. I’m basically fine.
Basically?
Am I a twin, Dad?
What does that have to --?
It’s a simple yes or no question. Am I a twin? Casey’s stern gaze gives Gordon pause. He back-tracks, sh his office door.
Yes. You had -- (correcting himself) -- you would have had a brother. He died while the two of you were still in utero. Upon hearing this, Casey’s agitated demeanor deflates.
How?
Casey, it was a long time ago --
Dad, I need to know.
(sighing) It was a freak thing. The placentas became fused. It’s not supposed to happen with fraternal twins.
And that caused him to die? Gordon looks pained. He really doesn’t want to elaborate.  24.
One of the umbilicals got twisted around his throat. Instinctively, Casey knows what’s about to come next.
My cord? Gordon nods. Casey blinks, trying to process it.
Why didn’t you ever tell me about this?
You have to understand -- it was a difficult period for your mother and I. And then, with everything that happened afterward -- He hates having to dredge all this up again.
By the time you were old enough to understand, it just didn’t seem relevant anymore.
Is that why Mom killed herself? Gordon is horrified at the suggestion.
Your mother was clinically depressed, Case.
And losing one of her kids pushed her over the edge.

No. See, this is exactly why I never brought any of this up. Your mother took her own life because she was mentally ill. Period. Now if you’re looking to ascribe blame you could point to me. Or her parents. Or society for making her feel inadequate. Or a million other things. (gentler) (MORE )
Or you can just accept the fact that some people come into this world less equipped for life than others.
Like my brother? Gordon shakes his head, saddened.
He was never your brother, Case. It was too early in the pregnancy for that. You have to understand -- we hadn’t fully accepted the reality of either of you guys.
Did he have a name?
Neither of you did yet. We just had nicknames for you.
What were they?
(smiling at the memory) You were Pongo. Something is gnawing at Casey now.
And what was his nickname?
Jumby. Casey blanches, ice water flooding her veins.

We SEE family vacations, childhood birthdays, school portraits of Casey. Beneath each photo is a dated caption penned in Janet’s meticulous print. Because the albums ar arranged chronologically, we are moving backwards in time

Baby photos of Casey, alongside her proud and happy paren We SEE Casey as a toddler, an infant, a newborn. Then Jan is pregnant, carrying the yet-to-be-born Casey. Casey and Romy make their way through a sparsely populate lounge. Romy looks around, unnerved. A few RESIDENTS play cards. Most simply sit by themselves.

The kid from your dream.
Yes.

Oh no. No. This is gonna be way too bizarro for me to miss out on. Plus, I love the smell in here. It’s like baby aspirin, mixed with old people's shit.
